content.webTitle: Philip Green: is it the end of the road for the retail king? | Observer profile

fields.headline: Philip Green: is it the end of the road for the retail king?
fields.bodyText: It is one of the great Hollywood courtroom scenes as Tom Cruise’s preppy lawyer needles the pride of Jack Nicholson’s pugnacious colonel until he explodes with rage and unleashes the devastating “you can’t handle the truth” rant that destroys him. Will MPs cross-examining Sir Philip Green on Wednesday be able to put in as good a performance as Cruise in a A Few Good Men and get under the skin of the famously short-tempered tycoon who is on the ropes for his role in the biggest British high-street collapse in nearly a decade? It’s obviously not a murder trial, although few would dispute that BHS suffered a slow death at the tycoon’s hands, but Green is on public trial for his decision to offload the 88-year-old chain to a consortium, led by a former racing driver and serial bankrupt Dominic Chappell, which had neither the financial firepower nor retail skills to pull off a turnaround that he, the King of High Street, had failed to effect. On Friday, the Daily Mail spoke for middle Britain with a front page that screamed: “Strip ‘Sir’ Shifty of his title”. An extreme censure that would put the once lauded businessman in the company of disgraced bank chief Fred Goodwin, who drove the Royal Bank of Scotland to the wall. The case against Green is that over an extended period his family and its other shareholders took out large sums of money from BHS, a tally of close to £600m in dividends, rental payments and interest on loans during 15 years of ownership. A year on from its sale to the consortium for £1, BHS is in administration and the taxpayer faces a £36m hit on unpaid VAT and statutory compensation owed to workers. Meanwhile, Arcadia, owned by his wife, Tina, which owns a host of other high street names including Miss Selfridge and Dorothy Perkins, is a secured creditor – the group first in line to receive money back from a liquidation – and stands to recoup £35m. Then there is the BHS pension fund that, with its £571m black hole, is being assessed for rescue by the Pension Protection Fund, the pensions lifeboat, an outcome that would surely shame a knight of the realm. Green is being pilloried by a press that gilded his reputation as a retail Midas capable of selling coals to Newcastle. His family’s fortune, much of it in the name of his Monaco-based wife, is put at £3.2bn, amassed via a series of deal in the 00s: BHS for £200m in 2000 and, two years later, the £800m purchase of Arcadia. The £1.2bn dividend the Greens paid themselves from Arcadia in 2005 still holds the record as the biggest payout in British corporate history. Critics of his business style argue his wealth has been amassed through clever financial engineering, cost-cutting and squeezing suppliers. Green’s lifestyle of conspicuous consumption – a new £100m super yacht, Lionheart, is on the way – relayed via paparazzi shots of him partying with Kate Moss and enjoying Caribbean getaways with Simon Cowell was tolerated while he was judged to be a wealth creator, but not now. Lord Myners, a former City minister who was chairman of Marks & Spencer when Green launched a takeover bid in 2004, is keen to get to the bottom of the BHS collapse. “We have learned that over an extended period Green took large sums of money out of BHS and underinvested in the business,” he said. “He also allowed a large pension deficit to arise and the pension trustees failed to take corrective action.” Some claim that Green was duped by Chappell, but Myners is sceptical: “It’s inconceivable that Philip Green could be duped by anyone in a financial transaction. I’ve learned that when dealing with Philip it’s best to sup with a long spoon.” At last week’s hearings, Chappell was described by Michael Hitchcock, a former consultant to BHS, as a “mythomaniac”, a term describing someone with “the tendency to lie, exaggerate or relate incredible imaginary adventures as if they had really happened”. So more The Secret Life of Walter Mitty than A Few Good Men. There was a further incredible plot twist as BHS’s chief executive, Darren Topp, told the committee Chappell had threatened to kill him after he accused him of stealing money. “He basically said, ‘It’s my business, I can do what I want. If you kick off about it I’m going to come down there and kill you...’ He says he was in the helicopter squad of the SAS and I know he has got a gun.” The idea that Chappell’s unsuitability as a custodian of BHS was lost on as shrewd a character as Green is one of the main areas MPs are grappling with. But so far the postmortem has been a circular firing squad. Frank Field, chairman of the work and pensions committee, said it was trying to establish whether Green had helped present a picture of Chappell as a credible buyer after it emerged a short-term transfer of funds from a property group had bolstered his credentials. “We are following the money,” explained Field, who has likened Green to “Banquo’s ghost” hanging over BHS even under new ownership. “We will be asking [Green]: ‘Have you asset stripped this company and destroyed 11,000 jobs and the proper payment of pensions to 22,000 pensioners?” On Friday night, it emerged Green was threatening not to appear unless Field resigned. The businessman is understood to be working on a proposal that could resolve the pension crisis but earlier that day the MP told the Financial Times the committee would “laugh” if he offered less than £600m to plug the pension fund. “I am not prepared to participate in a process which has not even the pretence of fairness and objectivity and which has as its primary objective the destruction of my reputation,” wrote Green in a letter to the Birkenhead MP. Green told the Observer he was “undecided” over whether to appear. Sports Direct founder, Mike Ashley, tried to stay away from an inquiry into his business but relented after he was told that he risked “lengthy and public” contempt hearings in parliament. Field was unmoved: “The House of Commons has asked me to chair and him to appear. I will chair and he will appear.” Imagine if it were the bones of M&S rather than BHS that were being picked over. It was Green’s attempt to wrest control of the national treasure in 2004 that earned his acceptance by the establishment, with onlookers impressed by the blue-chip backing he had attracted. Green, aged 64, was born in Croydon but grew up in Hampstead Garden Suburb, an affluent area in north London. He was sent to a Jewish boarding school in Oxfordshire but left at 15 with no O-levels. His father, a small businessman, died when he was 12, and Green started working with his entrepreneurial mother, Alma, who owned a portfolio of garages and car showrooms. He acquired his cockney swagger while serving an apprenticeship in the rag trade, importing jeans from the far east and opening a designer discount store in London. His first significant deal came in 1985 when he acquired Jean Jeanie, a struggling jeans business, for £65,000. Within a year, he had sold it for several million. He went on to run Amber Day, a discount clothes store quoted on the Stock Exchange, but didn’t fit into the corporate world. He was forced out by shareholders in 1992 and retreated to the private arena. One person who knows Green says his best qualities are “a great sense of humour” and “very loving family”. The couple have three children – a stepson, Brett Palos, from Tina’s first marriage plus Chloe and Brandon. Green’s acquaintance adds: “Philip has no spiritual or cultural side. He’s not interested in arts, music or theatre. He’s not well read and is non-active Jewish.” Few of the great and good who have attended Green’s famous birthday extravaganzas have stuck their neck out as the BHS saga unfolds. But they are now being pulled into the net of the inquiry, with Michael Sherwood, a senior Goldman Sachs banker and confidant, and the restauranteur Richard Caring, who owns the Ivy and was one of the original investors in BHS, now called as witnesses. Being knighted showed establishment approval for what Green felt he had achieved. “Stripping Green of his knighthood would for Lady Green be the most painful of all punishments, but it would be vindictive and inappropriate,” says Myners. “He is entitled to have his arguments heard and dealt with in the same way we would respond if the person concerned was a simple Mr Green.” • Comments will be opened later today THE GREEN FILE Born Croydon, 15 March 1952 Best of times Receiving a knighthood from the Tony Blair government for services to retail, sealing his membership of the business elite in 2006. “I think it is a nice honour – to have made your mark,” said Green at the time. Worst of times The collapse of BHS into administration has recast his public persona: no longer the “king of the high street”, he has been labelled the “unacceptable face of capitalism”. Having previously been celebrated for his business skills, the hundreds of millions of pounds his family banked from BHS are now being contrasted with the company’s failure and the gaping hole in its pension scheme. What he says “I was working as hard as I could and all these people beat me up. And you have all these people who can’t even spell business or retail saying, ‘Oh, we don’t want people like him.’ Snooty tooty people.” What others say “The volcanoes erupt frequently. He’s very sensitive but I think that for all people like Philip, insecurity is a factor, because in their minds they have got to continue to be successful…There’s a very childish side to Philip that looks for affection.” Ian Grabiner, chief executive of Arcadia.
